Award.AwardTitle: Geotechnical Site Characterization with 3-D Seismic Waveform Tomography

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Unanticipated site conditions such as highly variable soil and rock layers with embedded low-velocity anomalies (soft soils or voids) cause significant problems during and after construction of foundations. Knowledge of the anomalies is crucial, as the anomalies can cause structural damage or collapse that can result in significant property damage and occasional loss of life. This award supports fundamental research to provide the knowledge needed to quantify embedded anomalies and characterize variable soil/rock layers at high resolutions. Results from this research will accelerate economical and practical implementation of innovative non-destructive testing (NDT) methods for protecting and improving our nation's infrastructure. The developed analysis can be used for material imaging and characterization at various scales from millimeters to hundreds of meters for several engineering applications such as evaluation of geotechnical subsurface site conditions, bridge foundation scour, concrete structural components, and asphalt pavements.

The goal of this research is to characterize both shear wave (S-wave) and compression wave (P-wave) velocity profiles of 3-D subsurface structures at meter scales down to 30 meter depth from surface-based seismic wave fields. The subsurface structures consist of soil, rock, and voids filled by air or water. To achieve the goal, the research will include (i) to develop a three-dimensional full waveform inversion (3-D FWI) analysis of seismic wave fields for high-resolution (meter pixel) characterization of subsurface site conditions, and (ii) to verify the 3-D FWI analysis by full scale field experiments. Full seismic surface wave fields will be used to quantify embedded anomalies and characterize variable soil/rock layers, as the propagation properties of seismic waves are modulated by the anomalies and layer interfaces. The seismic wave fields are acquired from geophysical testing using sensors and sources located in uniform 2-D grids on the ground surface, and then inverted for the extraction of 3-D subsurface wave velocity structures. The research will address inherent issues of small scale tomography including dominant Rayleigh wave components, inconsistent wave excitation, strong attenuation, poor a priori information, and highly variable of near surface soil/rock. Using full information contained in the measured waveform data, the FWI analysis is expected to provide more detailed and accurate characterization of materials than methods currently used in practice, which use only portions of the measured data. This will result in new knowledge in the area of engineering geophysics, and it is a critical step toward using an effective geophysical method for site investigations to improve design of foundations and other geotechnical structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Unanticipated site conditions such as highly variable soil/rock layers with embedded low-velocity anomalies (soft soils or voids) cause significant problems during and after construction of foundations. Knowledge of the anomalies is crucial, as the anomalies can cause structural damage or collapse that can result in significant property damage and occasional loss of life. For example, several recent sinkhole events in central Florida have caused human deaths, collapsed many houses, and destroyed a resort complex near Disney World. These dramatic events are just extreme cases, which stand out from a big stream of property damage due to poor site characterization. The goal of the project is to advance geophysical testing for 3D geotechnical site characterization to improve design and construction of foundations and other subsurface structures. During the project, we have successfully developed a novel 3D full-waveform inversion (3D FWI) method using surface-based seismic wavefields for geotechnical site investigation at high-resolution. The method is based on the solution of 3D elastic wave equations, and Gauss-Newton optimization. The seismic wavefields are acquired from non-invasive geophysical testing using sensors and sources located in uniform 2D grids on the ground surface, and then inverted for extraction of 3D subsurface soil/rock properties.

 

The developed 3D FWI method has several transformative aspects. First, both shear wave (S-wave) and pressure wave (P-wave) velocities can be inverted simultaneously, as all possible wave types [S-waves, P-waves, and Rayleigh waves] propagating at different velocities and in various directions in 3D domain are measured by a 2D grid of sensors on the ground surface and used for analyses. Second, Gauss-Newton optimization offers more accurate inversion results than gradient methods commonly used for FWI, as inverse Hessian matrix used in Gauss-Newton method sharpens, filters, and balances the gradient vector, resulting in higher resolution and fewer artifacts. Third, embedded anomalies (soft soils or voids) can be well detected, as signals reflected and refracted from the anomalies at different angles are utilized for analyses. Fourth, off-line anomalies, which cannot be accurately detected by 2D analyses (e.g. 2D FWI or refraction) because of the 3D effect, can be characterized by the 3D analysis, as the 3D FWI analysis completely handles the 3D effect problem.  Lastly, the 3D analysis requires less field testing efforts to detect an anomaly than the 2D analysis. The 2D approach requires seismic data to be acquired right on the top of the anomaly, and thus multiple test lines are usually needed because of the unknown location of the anomaly. Whereas the 3D FWI only requires data to be acquired in the vicinity of the anomaly, since signals reflected and refracted from the anomaly in various angles can be recorded by a 2D grid of sensors on the ground surface.

The developed 3D FWI method has produced excellent results on both synthetic (computational) and field experiments. The analyzed results from synthetic datasets show great capabilities of the method in characterizing laterally variable low- and high-velocity layers, and in detecting buried voids at various depths. Comparing the conventional FWI analyses based on the classic cross-adjoint inversion, our method based on Gauss-Newton inversion provides more accurate and higher resolution inverted results. Accurate field results are obtained at four different test sites in Florida.  A known cavity (culvert), unknown buried voids (pre-collapsed sinkholes) at both shallow depths of 5 m to 10 m and larger depths up to 40 m, and variable soil/rock layers are well characterized and confirmed by the ground truth.

This research enables new capabilities of subsurface imaging and characterization in terms of accuracy and resolution that were previously unobtainable. True 3D material properties of the subsurface can be characterized non-intrusively at meter-pixel (3D cells) to 30-meter depth and two-meter-pixel to 50-meter depth for imaging soil/rock layering and buried anomalies. These detailed material properties help improve the design and construction of substructures, as they can be used for several geotechnical analyses such as foundation settlement, bearing capacity, lateral ground movement due to excavation, and earthquake site response. The new capabilities of imaging the subsurface and retrieving reliable geo-material properties would influence hazard engineering for more resilient and sustainable infrastructure. They would also have positive impacts on other disciplines such as natural resource exploration, subsurface hydrology, and underground development. The research from this project has been published in six peer-reviewed journal articles: Nguyen and Tran, 2018; Mirzanejad and Tran, 2019; Tran et al., 2019; Tran et al., 2020; Mirzanejad et al. 2020a; and  Mirzanejad et al. 2020b, and presented at five technical conferences/NSF workshops.
